nodes.bodyText: Why remove this? This is exactly what we were trying to test for...
Now that we match mocks to match server behavior the test breaks.
Given that these classes will get rewritten anyway with PDP-34 and that even right now, nobody accesses them directly except via RollingStorage, I think we should be fine with this change.

Here we have BoundedInputStream and the Length of Inputstream (or length to be written) - both are used to control the boundary? Not very clear about the relationship between the two - who's taking priority if the two values conflicting?
Actually the requirement is that we want them to be same. That's why we pass same writeLength on line 331 and 332.

InputStreams do not have lengths. They have available() but that doesn't tell you much.
You need to pass the length to the API to tell it how much to write.
You need to (now) use a BoundedInputStream with a specific bound because some of those Tier 2 APIs do not respect that value. We want to make sure they do not under- or over-read.

Then option 1 would be to create another method called "writeWithBoundedInputStream" to encapsulate this logic;
option 2: at least add a runtime assert here to call out the logic.
option 3: inside write() checks if the incoming InputStream is BoundedIS, if it is, honor the boundary defined by it.
A method calling with overlapping input data is confusing hence error-prone.
Can the 3 rollovers be reflected in the test code?
We write 10 bytes, with max rolling length set to 3.
